Impossible. A heterozygote for an allele can never produce another heterozygous individual because heterozygosity implies a mixture of different alleles at one locus.
The cross Blue x Green would have to be BB(blue) x GT(Turquoise) or any other combination where both individuals carry the same allele on their two homologues, producing four offsprings that are all heterozygotes for this allele. The only way to achieve a heterogeneous result would be if one parent was hemizygous but there is no mention of this being the case so I assume it's not.

data.sampled:
It's not possible to determine the exact genotypes from just the phenotypic ratios provided in the problem statement. The information about dominance (B > G > T) can help us make some educated guesses though.

Assuming that both parents are heterozygous for all loci involved in determining wing color, we could have four different possible combinations:

* BB : Two dominant alleles for blue wings
* BT : A dominant allele for blue wings and a recessive allele for turquoise wings
* GT : A dominant allele for turquoise wings and a recessive allele for green wings
* GG : Two recessive alleles for green wings

If these assumptions hold true, then it would mean that we got a 3:1 ratio of blue:turquoise wings in the F1-generation when crossing two blue individuals. This suggests that at least one of the parents must carry either a dominant or a recessive allele for blue wings (either BB or BT).

However, without more information on the specific ratios observed in the F1-population, there isn't enough data to determine which combination of genotypes was present among the parents. Therefore I cannot give you an accurate answer to this question, sorry!

data.sampled:
It's not possible to have an exact distribution of 3/4 Blue and 1/4 Turquoise for this cross because the Turquoise color only occurs when both copies of the gene are heterozygous (Turquoise). However, if we assume that there is some small probability of random mutations occurring during gamete formation or fertilization, then it may be possible to obtain such a ratio.
If we consider the possibility of mutation and use binomial probabilities, the expected frequency of Turquoise would be approximately 0.5^2 = 0.25. This means that out of every four offspring produced from crossing two Blue-winged parents, one offspring should exhibit the Turquoise color.
Therefore, the most likely genotype of the offspring would be BB (Blue) or B_ (Blue), since these represent the homozygous dominant form of the gene, which produces the Blue color. The remaining offspring would be heterozygous for the gene, meaning they could either be BB (Blue) or BT (Turquoise). Since we expect only about 25% of the offspring to display the Turquoise color, it is more likely that the remaining 75% will display the Blue color.
In conclusion, it is theoretically possible but unlikely to produce an offspring with Turquoise wings from a cross between two Blue-winged parents. The most probable outcome would be for all offspring to inherit the dominant Blue allele, resulting in a phenotypic ratio of 3/4 Blue and 1/4 Green.

data.sampled:
The correct answer for this problem is "Green x Green -> 50% Blue (dominant), 25% Green (recessive), 25% Turquoise (co-dominant)." This means that when two green beetles are crossed, their offspring will have a variety of different wing colors depending on which dominant or recessive alleles they inherit from their parents. Some examples include:

* Green x Green -> 1/2 BB, 1/2 gg
* Green x Green -> 1/4 BB, 1/4 GG, 1/2 gg
* Green x Green -> 1/4 BB, 1/4 gg, 1/4 GT, 1/4 tt

These combinations demonstrate how dominant and recessive traits can appear in an organism's offspring based on its genetic makeup. For example, if a beetle inherits two dominant B alleles, it will display the bluish-green color; if it inherits one dominant and one recessive gene, it will display the green color; if it inherits both recessive genes, it will display the brown color. By understanding these patterns, researchers can better predict the outcomes of crossbreeding experiments involving these types of beetles.
